subject: Re: [junit] JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: ... Hi David I have been playing around with Agitator and also attended a presentation by Jeff Frederick from Agitar about Developer testing.  Two things ...
messageBody:
On 5/27/06, davek725 <david.kissinger@...> wrote:

> 1. Agitator looks like it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit
> tests (except true persistence testing). The downside is that we
> would be left with only Agitator config files that contain our
> business logic assertions. This seems like a big leap to take, given
> that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.



Hi David

I have been playing around with Agitator and also attended a presentation by
Jeff Frederick from Agitar about Developer testing. Two things ... 1.
Agitar have realised that they have pushed the product thing a bit too far;
and 2. Agitator is not a replacement for JUnit and I have not seen anyone
suggest that.

Have a look for a thread on the TDD group where I asked a similar question
to you .. and Jeff responded. They wrote up their experiences TDD their
Dashboard product using JUnit and Agitator. It's titled the XPeriment (or
something similar).

Jeff also had some slides on Agitation Driven Refactorings which looked
interesting. Where I can see agiation adding value is in the example they
found where a method took a string. It then tried to instantiate a class
from that string. Agitator looked at the method and went "it takes a string
... well let's try any string then" ... and so identfied an area that could
cause a bug.

I have been trying to agitate the bowling game to see what refactorings it
drives me to do.

Anyway bottom line, I think the product compliments JUnit and TDD ... I am
just not sure on how much that is yet.


Cheers
Shane


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
